Investment Proposal  Investment of up to $30 million in CNY equivalent (or, if ADB is 
unable to fund CNY, in US dollars) in Hangzhou City Commercial 
Bank Co., Ltd. (HZCCB) in the People’s Republic of China (PRC), 
for  approximately  5%  of  the  total  outstanding  shares,  as  an 
important step in reforming the PRC commercial banking sector 
on the city level.

Rationale and  An  efficient  financial  system  promotes  sustainable  economic 
Justification  growth,  which  generates  employment  and  reduces  poverty. 
Financial intermediation, particularly through the banking sector, is 
the  main  engine  for  economic  growth.  The  banking  sector 
dominates  the  financial  system  in  the  PRC.  However,  the 
inefficiency of the sector has been identified as one of the greatest 
obstacles to long-term growth, especially the limited access of 
small and medium-sized enterprises (SME) to financing.  
 
Recognizing  the  need  to  improve  the  banking  sector,  the 
Government of the PRC has encouraged the reform of its banks, 
especially  state-owned  commercial  banks  (SOCB).  For  certain 
qualified banks, the Government has promoted the involvement of 
private domestic and foreign strategic investors. The first stage of 
reforms targeted the “big four” SOCBs. Now the focus of reforms 
is on the network of 112 city commercial banks (CCB) that serve 
major urban areas throughout the PRC. These CCBs play—and 
will continue to play—a vital role in and around the cities they 
serve, especially in SME development. However, CCBs will have 
to  address  some  significant  issues  before  they  can  improve, 
including  strategic  risk,  poor  corporate  governance,  weak  risk 
management, and low capital adequacy ratios.  
 
The success of PRC’s banking reforms, SME development, and 
economic growth hinges on the ability of PRC banks, especially 
the CCBs, to address these challenges properly. The Government 
views  the  introduction  of  experienced  and  qualified  overseas 
strategic investors as an effective method to promote, as well as

ii   
to  enhance,  this  reform  process.  However,  while  the  growth 
prospects  of  PRC’s  banking  sector  are  attractive  to  investors, 
international banks remain wary of taking minority stakes even in 
relatively higher-quality CCBs. Their main concerns are (i) the 
untested  governance  framework;  (ii)  the  strategic  partner’s 
potential  inability  as  minority  investor  to  influence  strategic 
direction,  management,  and  equity  distributions;  and  (iii) 
uncertainty over the continued role of local government. 
   
Value-Added  Through  this  investment,  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB) 
delivers  value  to  HZCCB  by  assisting  in  the  development  of 
adequate corporate governance and internal control procedures, 
as well as in opportunities for commercial cooperation. ADB also 
adds value to HZCCB’s shareholders by fulfilling the role of an 
“honest broker” that has only the bank’s best interests at heart. 
   
Development Impact  An  investment  in  HZCCB  would  impact  development  by  (i) 
promoting the development of a lagging financial sector, thereby 
increasing access to finance for SMEs, in a showcase region with 
strong  private  sector,  SME-driven  economic  development;  (ii) 
supporting  the  transformation  of  a  leading  CCB,  especially  in 
corporate  governance,  internal  control,  and  environmental 
sensibility, which would send a strong demonstration signal to 
other  CCBs  in  the  country;  (iii)  demonstrating  feasibility  and 
providing  market  benchmarks  for  similar  investments  in  other 
CCBs, and helping to catalyze such investments; (iv) indirectly 
fostering  economic  development  of  non-coastal  regions  in  the 
PRC; and (iv) supporting the Government’s efforts to restructure 
the banking sector.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed 
equity investment of up to $30 million in CNY equivalent (or, if ADB is unable to fund in CNY, in 
US dollars) for approximately 5% of the shares in Hangzhou City Commercial Bank, Co. Ltd 
(HZCCB), in the People’s Republic of China (PRC) (the Project). 
 
II.  BACKGROUND AND RATIONALE 
A.  PRC Economic Development and Industry Background  
1.  Overview of Latest Developments in the PRC Economy 
2.  In recent years, the PRC has made progress in restructuring its economy, especially by 
reducing its dependence on Government spending and increasing the performance of its state-
owned enterprise (SOE) sector. On the surface, the PRC possesses a respectable credit profile 
(Standard & Poors: A-, Moody’s: A2, Fitch: A-). The economy features rapid growth rates, high 
savings and investment rates, low Government and external debt, and stable long-term capital 
inflows. Driven by buoyant domestic investment and exports, gross domestic product (GDP) 
growth has exceeded 9% for 4 straight years, including 9.9% in 2005. The PRC’s key strength, 
however, lies in its strong external balance. The current account surplus is about three times the 
countries external debt, while reserves cover its external debt three times and short-term debt 
five times. The economic expansion continued in the first quarter of 2006, as real GDP grew 
10.2% compared with the same period in 2005—much faster than the Government’s full-year 
projection of 8% growth. Investment and exports continued to propel growth in the first quarter. 
Exports increased 26.6% year-on-year, helping to boost official foreign exchange reserves to 
$875 billion at the end of March from $819 billion 3 months earlier. Yet economic reforms, as 
well as social and environmental issues, will continue to present challenges for the foreseeable 
future. An economic summary of the PRC is in Appendix 1. 
 
2.  Small and Medium-Sized Enterprises in the PRC: Driving Growth 
 
3.  Small and medium-sized enterprises (SME)1 play a significant role in the PRC economy, 
driving employment, economic growth, and development. They account for almost half of GDP, 
two thirds of industrial value added, 60% of exports, and 40% of fiscal revenues.2 SMEs also 
provide 75% of urban and rural employment. Private sector SMEs have grown faster than the 
larger SOEs. In recent years, the industrial output of SMEs has been increasing at an annual 
average  rate  of  30%,  compared  with  20%  for  industry  as  a  whole.3 Consequently,  the 
development of the SME sector is regarded as more than an important engine of growth. It is 
considered a key contributor to poverty reduction by generating jobs, individual income, and tax 
revenues. 
 
4.  SMEs rely heavily on access to external capital to finance their operations. However, a 
survey by the State Information Center found that more than 80% of the PRC’s SMEs have 
difficulty accessing financial services and securing financing.4 Although bank loans in the PRC

3.  Overview of the PRC Financial System  
5.  The banking sector plays a dominant role in the PRC’s financial system. At the end of 
September 2005, the PRC’s commercial banking system comprised (i) four national state-
owned commercial banks (SOCB), (ii) 13 national joint-stock commercial banks (JSCB), (iii) 112 
city commercial banks (CCB), (iv) 57 rural cooperative and commercial banks, (v) 626 urban 
credit cooperatives, (vi) about 30,000 rural credit cooperatives, and (vii) 238 operational entities 
of foreign banks.5 The four SOCBs dominate the sector, together accounting for 54% of banking 
sector assets, followed by the JSCBs (15%), and the CCBs (5%) (Table 1; Appendix 2, Figure 
A2.1). Foreign banks account for less than 2% of market share.

6.  In  the  PRC,  the  ratio  of  bank  assets  to  stock  market  capitalization  plus  bonds

common in many developing economies. In the PRC, however, it is particularly important due to 
the large market size and fast growth. The PRC’s financial institution assets have grown at a 
compounded annual growth rate (CAGR) of 13% since 2000, reaching $4.9 trillion at the end of 
March 2006—about the same as the United Kingdom’s financial sector (Appendix 2, Figure 
A2.2). 
 
7.  The banking sector is at the center of the Government’s economic reforms. Measures to 
clean up the banks have improved asset quality and capitalization, and in many instances risk 
management. However, uncertainties over the quality of banks’ assets remain. In addition, 
limited foreign participation in the sector and cultural resistance to foreign influence might 
constrain the pace of reforms. The recapitalization costs for the banking system are a moving 
target,  and  one  of  the  major  risk  factors  constraining  the  PRC’s  credit  profile  and  future

B.  City Commercial Banks in the PRC Banking Sector 
1.  Overview  
8.  The CCBs were formed through Government-directed amalgamations of urban credit 
cooperatives (UCC) in the mid to late 1990s. This amalgamation was partly a response to 
galloping NPLs created by the unsustainable UCCs, and partly an effort to consolidate the 
financial  sector  to  achieve  economies  of  scale.  During  this  process,  however,  the  CCBs 
received full financial and managerial support by their respective city governments. Moreover, 
only one CCB was created in each city (i.e., no competition for Government favors). Thus, 
CCBs remained a de facto part of the city governments’ economic planning apparatus. This 
included significant directed lending to government priority projects and SOEs.  
 
9.  Typically, CCBs still maintain very strong ties to their respective city governments. In 
many cities, the respective governments still hold majority equity stakes. Some progressive 
CCBs have diversified shareholdings, which include local private and state-owned companies, 
as well as upgraded employees with increasing commercial skills. However, few CCBs have 
substantial private investment, and none is listed on any stock exchange.  
 
10.  Although CCBs play an important role in their respective local banking sectors, their 
contribution  to  the  PRC’s  financial  sector  is  still  relatively  small.  Together,  the  112  CCBs 
account for slightly more than 5% of the PRC banking sector’s assets. Although small by 
comparison to other banks in the PRC, CCBs serve cities that can be very large—as large as 
small countries in some cases. For example, Bank of Beijing, Bank of Shanghai, and Chongqing 
City Commercial Bank all operate in markets with populations of more than 10 million. Tianjin 
has a population of 7.6 million, while Hangzhou has 3.9 million people.  
 
11.  At the end of March 2006, CCB assets totaled CNY2.1 trillion, while CCB equity was 
CNY83.2 billion, according to CBRC. The average CCB NPL ratio was 7.6% at the end of March 
2006, compared with an average of 8.0% for the entire banking sector. In many cities, however, 
the NPL ratio is still above 20%. As of March 2006, the weighted average capital adequacy ratio 
for the CCB subsector had increased significantly to more than 5%, but remained below the 
required 8%. 
 
2.  Issues Facing CCBs and Policy Reform Initiatives 
12.  The CCBs have the potential to continue growing at a healthy rate in line with the PRC’s 
economy and banking sector. One forecaster anticipates CCBs will grow at a CAGR of 26%, 
reaching nearly $656 billion in assets by 2009.7  
 
13.  However, most CCBs will have difficulty sustaining growth rates without jeopardizing 
asset  quality  and  capital  adequacy.  To  provide  competitive,  customer-driven  services  and 
products targeted at underserved segments of the markets in cities and regions of the PRC, the 
CCBs will have to develop their capabilities quickly to match those of a modern banking sector.

In this process, the CCBs will have to address some key issues, including (i) limited access to 
state-of-the-art banking technology and know-how, (ii) lack of economies of scale in funding, (iii) 
undercapitalization and high levels of NPLs, (iv) a legacy of government influence in strategic 
focus and in management, (v) lack of competitive experience due to the favored position in the 
respective city, (vi) a history of deficient corporate governance and internal controls, and (vii) 
limited growth prospects within each respective city. 
 
14.  To address these issues, several logical evolutionary steps are needed for this sector: (i) 
tie-ups with (foreign) strategic partners that can bring operational know-how, a competitive 
mindset, better governance, and capital; (ii) sales of significant equity stakes to nongovernment 
entities to dilute the influence of, and reliance on, the local government; (iii) cessation of further 
Government support to undercapitalized banks that are unable to meet CBRC capital adequacy 
requirements by the prescribed deadlines; (iv) opening up of cities to competition from other 
CCBs (initially from the same province, but eventually CCBs from any part of the country); and 
(v)  consolidation  of  CCBs  into  fewer,  stronger  banks  that  are  more  capable  of  exploring 
economies of scale. 
 
15.  The CBRC has outlined a four-point reform strategy to enhance the development and 
supervision of CCBs:8 (i) CCBs should define clear market strategies to focus on local residents 
and SMEs, playing to their inherent competitive advantages; (ii) CCBs should resolve impaired 
assets through close cooperation with local governments and other means, such as asset 
swaps and the introduction of qualified strategic investors; (iii) CCBs should improve their 
corporate governance structure and mechanisms; and (iv) the CBRC will adopt differentiated 
policies and approaches in supervising different categories of CCBs, allowing a larger scope of 
operations for CCBs with sound management and good business performance, while preparing 
a “market exit” for CCBs with high risks. Accordingly, the CBRC approved the first cross-city 
expansion, allowing Bank of Shanghai to set up a branch in Ningbo. Further, six CCBs and 
seven  UCCs  in  Anhui  Province  were  restructured  recently  into  Huishang  Bank—the  first 
regional commercial bank in the PRC created from the restructuring of local financial institutions 
within one province. 
 
3.  CCBs as Investment Opportunities 
16.  Several international financial institutions have invested in PRC commercial banks, using 
their  investments  as  a  tool  to  understand  the  country’s  banking  industry  and  accumulate 
operating  experience.  However,  the  integration  of  the  PRC  banking  industry  into  the 
international market is in its infancy. In light of the huge opportunities in the PRC market, foreign 
banks are facing the challenge of how to formulate and implement their PRC development 
strategies. With the overwhelming size and limited availability of the SOCBs, foreign banks are 
looking at JSCBs and CCBs as appropriate investments for entry into the PRC banking sector. 
 
17.  The  economic  profile  of  the  city  where  a  bank  is  located  largely  determines  the 
commercial attractiveness of an investment in a CCB.  Generally, this is a function of the 
population size, economic growth prospects, and investment climate. In addition, the targeted 
bank  must  have  acceptable  asset  quality,  market  position,  and  management  willing  to 
implement  changes.  Forbes  magazine  ranked  the  PRC  cities  with  the  best  investment 
environments: Hangzhou, Guangzhou, Shanghai, and Shenzhen. It also ranked the top ten

18.  Not all of the 112 CCBs will be able to attract quality strategic partners, however. Thus, 
in the medium to long run, only a handful is expected to lead the consolidation and market 
expansion efforts. The Private Sector Operations Division (PSOP) of ADB believes that only the 
top 15–20 CCBs will find suitable strategic investors, and 30–40 at most will survive in the long 
term. In line with this assessment, the Government appears prepared to take a hard stance 
against  supporting  CCBs  operating  with  high  risks,  including  contemplating  closure.11 The 
survivors will be the ones willing to change. To increase long-term viability and attractiveness to 
potential strategic partners, leading CCBs have focused over the past 2–3 years on improving 
asset quality, management, systems, and operations. Despite these efforts, only a few CCBs 
have announced or completed equity investments with foreign strategic partners.12 
 
III.  THE PROPOSED INVESTMENT 
19.  The proposed investment involves an equity participation of up to $30 million (or CNY 
equivalent) in HZCCB in the PRC, for approximately 5% of the bank’s outstanding shares.13  
 
A.  Project Selection 
20.  ADB uses a sector-wide portfolio approach to its financial sector investments in the 
PRC. Landmark projects in each subsector are identified and pursued based on their potential 
demonstration effect and replicability by other institutions in the same subsector. To this end, 
ADB has invested in one SOCB (Bank of China); one JSCB (China Everbright Bank); Xiamen 
International Bank, a foreign bank; and Credit Orienwise, a credit guarantee company based in 
Shenzhen. Separately, ADB is pursuing other opportunities in the credit cooperative, rural bank, 
and  nonbank  subsectors.  As  such,  the  development  effects  of  ADB’s  resources  are 
appropriately leveraged across the sector, and portfolio risk is diversified. 
 
21.  In  conjunction  with  the  East  Asia  Regional  Department  (EARD),  PSOP  made  the 
strategic  decision  to  move  into  the  PRC’s  CCB  subsector.  The  efforts  to  target  the  CCB 
subsector began in early 2004 as a result of a joint PSOP-EARD mission to Tianjin and Dalian. 
This mission generated a clear understanding that a successful demonstration effect from an 
investment in a CCB requires: (i) a local government supportive of change, and willing to modify 
and delineate its ownership role; (ii) a management team in place with a proven track record, a 
vision of strategic change, and the capability to implement it; (iii) a strong international strategic 
partner with expressed desire to invest in the CCB and cooperate with ADB; (iv) a local market

22.  CCBs with these characteristics would produce the demonstration effect ADB is seeking. 
Therefore, ADB must team up with (i) a strong strategic investor that is willing to invest know-
how as well as capital, and (ii) a CCB that is open to change. Based on an initial market 
assessment and ranking of CCBs, PSOP undertook desktop analyses of some 20 CCBs. From 
this group, PSOP held initial meetings with seven CCBs during 2004 and 2005. PSOP also 
discussed potential targets with several international commercial banks interested in investing in 
CCBs in the PRC. From this process, HZCCB emerged as one of the preferred potential 
investment targets. 
 
23.  Commonwealth Bank of Australia (CBA) also approached ADB to gauge its interest in 
investing in HZCCB. This was a natural progression from several discussions between ADB and 
CBA over the previous year regarding possible cooperation and co-investment in the financial 
sector in the PRC. CBA is interested in establishing a long-term relationship with ADB for follow-
up investments in other regions of the PRC (especially Inner Mongolia and Western PRC), as 
well as other ADB developing member countries (DMC). ADB indicated its interest in a co-
investment with CBA in HZCCB. However, due to a longer processing schedule, ADB noted that 
its own investment might not be ready at the same time as CBA’s.  
 
24.  HZCCB had been in discussions with other potential investors alongside CBA, including 
the  bilateral  German  development  corporation  Deutsche  Entwicklungs-Gesellschaft,  the 
International  Finance  Corporation  (IFC),  and  Temasek  Holdings  of  Singapore.  Following 
interactions over the next 3 months, HZCCB and the local government decided that ADB would 
be their preferred partner.  
 
25.  ADB’s investments in the PRC over the past 2 years have refreshed the view in the 
international investment banking community of ADB as a credible investment partner that can 
add significant value. As such, ADB should build on this momentum to maximize the catalytic 
effect its activities are yielding. ADB would strengthen its track record for follow-up investments 
in partnership with international commercial banks, especially in less-developed regions of the 
PRC (and elsewhere in the region), as well as in other selected subsectors of the PRC financial 
system. 
 
B.  The Investee Company: Hangzhou City Commercial Bank 
1.  Overview 
26.  HZCCB was formed in 1996 through the amalgamation of the Hangzhou’s 33 UCCs. At

V.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 
A.  Justification for the ADB Investment  
1.  Investment Rationale 
 
34.  An efficient financial system promotes sustainable economic growth, which generates 
employment and reduces poverty. Financial intermediation, particularly through the banking 
sector, is the main engine for economic growth. The banking sector dominates the financial 
system in the PRC. However, the inefficiency of the sector has been identified as one of the 
greatest  obstacles  to  long-term  growth,  especially  with  regard  to  SMEs.  (Appendix  1). 
Recognizing the need to improve the banking sector, the Government has encouraged its 
banks, especially SOCBs, to undergo reform. For certain qualified banks, the Government has 
promoted the involvement of private domestic and foreign strategic investors. The first stage of 
reforms targeted the “big four” SOCBs. Now the focus of reforms is on the network of 112 CCBs 
that serve major urban areas throughout the PRC. These CCBs play—and will continue to 
play—a vital role in and around the cities they serve, especially in SME development. However, 
CCBs will have to address some significant issues before they can improve, including strategic 
risk, poor corporate governance, weak risk management, and low capital adequacy ratios. The 
success of the PRC’s banking reforms, SME development, and economic growth hinges on the 
ability of the PRC banks, especially the CCBs, to address these challenges properly. 
 
35.  CBRC views the introduction of experienced and qualified overseas strategic investors 
as an effective method to promote and enhance this reform process.17 On the micro level, the 
sale of strategic stakes in these banks boosts capital, dilutes government influence, provides 
access to strategic and operational know-how, and brings better corporate governance. The 
enhanced strategic focus and increased capital also will help the bank become more prepared 
for competition in its home market. Further, this will enable the bank to take advantage of 
growth opportunities in new markets via acquisitions, mergers, or strategic cooperation with 
banks in other cities and provinces; or via greenfield organic establishment in such markets. 
However, while the growth prospects of the PRC’s banking sector are attractive to investors, 
international banks remain wary of taking minority stakes even in relatively higher-quality CCBs. 
Their main concerns are (i) the untested governance framework; (ii) the strategic partner’s 
potential inability as minority investor to influence strategic direction, management, and equity 
distributions; and (iii) uncertainty over the continued role of local government. 
 
36.  In summary, the overall progress of PRC banks is still lagging behind banks in other 
countries in the region. The lack of a consistent nationwide credit database impedes lending

A.   Main Considerations in Banking Sector and Capital Markets 
 
1.  Overview. Despite the monetary and financial sector reforms,2 the financial sector does 
not meet the needs of a market economy. Indirect monetary policy instruments (e.g., open 
market  operations)  are  not  fully  developed  and  interest rate  policy  remains  inflexible.  The 
regulatory and supervisory framework for banks and nonbank financial institutions remains 
weak.  Despite  substantial  progress, 3  the  capital  markets  are  underdeveloped  and  not 
adequately  regulated  and  supervised.  Weaknesses  in  the  banking  sector,  high  levels  of 
nonperforming loan (NPLs), incomplete state-owned enterprise (SOE) reforms, and incomplete 
pension reforms remain causes of concern. The People’s Bank of China (PBOC), the China 
Securities  Regulatory  Commission  (CSRC),  the  China  Insurance  Regulatory  Commission 
(CIRC),  and  the  China  Banking  Regulatory  Commission  (CBRC)  are  placing  increased 
emphasis on improving corporate governance in the financial sector. 
 
2.  Since  2003,  banking  sector  regulatory  and  supervisory  responsibilities  have  been 
divided between PBOC and CBRC. PBOC, guided by the State Council, is responsible for 
formulating and implementing monetary policy and for enacting safeguards to ensure financial 
stability. CBRC is the main regulator of the banking sector and its responsibilities include 
formulating and enforcing the supervisory rules and regulations governing bank institutions. 
 
3.  Banking. There are 4 state-owned commercial banks (SOCBs),4 3 policy banks,5 12 
joint-stock  banks,  112  city  commercial  banks  (CCBs),  as  well  as  foreign  banks.6 Banking 
dominates the financial market with around 80% share in total assets.7 The profitability of 
SOCBs and the policy banks is lower than what would be acceptable to commercial banks in a 
market economy. SOCBs and policy banks have devoted most of their lending to SOEs or 
designated development projects, while the joint-stock and city commercial banks are more 
private sector-oriented and lend to small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs).8 
 
4.  Plans are implemented to modernize SOCBs and the joint-stock commercial banks have 
been encouraged to merge and restructure. The SOCBs will be corporatized as an initial step in 
the restructuring process. Over the last 4 years, they have closed more than 21,000 branch 
offices and shed more than 100,000 personnel. The joint-stock commercial banks are now 
moving to list on the stock exchanges. 
 
5.  The PRC regulators place numerous restrictions on permissible products, services, and 
activities of domestic and foreign banks. For example, there are still restrictions on commercial 
banks offering fee-based products. Interest rates on loans and deposits offered by commercial 
banks are still subject to PBOC regulations even after recent reform measures that gave banks

15.  Corporate banking will remain the primary focus of the PRC banking industry in the near

D.  Summary: Main Credit Consideration 
 
22.  The outlook on PRC banking industry is positive and economic risk and industry risk 
have improved. Although the system still faces some major challenges, government actions 
taken in the past two years signify that industry reform is taking a major step forward. While the 
sector  is  still  characterized  by  ineffectual  corporate  governance,  weak  asset  quality,  low 
profitability, and low capitalization, direct and indirect capital injections from the Government, 
and reform efforts by the banks themselves have helped the sector to improve its financial 
profile. In addition, intensifying supervisory efforts by regulators are slowly shaping the industry. 
Given time, these efforts are likely to lay a solid foundation for the sector to build on. However, 
financial sector reform in the PRC is still very much a work in progress, and setbacks along the 
road  are  only  to  be  expected.  Positive  factors  to  take  into  consideration  are: (i)  a  strong 
economy; (ii) government support; (iii) high level of commitment; (iv) improving ability to manage 
economy; (v) strengthening regulatory oversight; (vi) strengthening corporate sector.

to positively impact development depends on various indicators of its “healthiness”, through 
both  qualitative  and  quantitative  measures,  as  well  as  broader  impact  beyond  HZCCB. 
Development  indicators  can  be  categorized along  two  key  parameters  within  the  Project’s 
impact on private sector development via: (i) Project (direct) Company impact that the Project 
delivers to and/or by HZCCB; and (ii) Beyond (indirect) Company impact to the wider sector 
and/or economy that are outside the specific activities of HZCCB.
